name: Puputan Klungkung monument
address: FC83+397, Central Semarapura, Klungkung, Klungkung Regency, Bali 80761, Indonesia
review 1:
KLUNGKUNG (a brief overview and history)

From Gelgel to Semarapura and Puputan (17th Century - 1908)

The 17th century marked a significant shift in Balinese governance. Prior to this, the powerful kingdom of Gelgel held sway over much of the island. However, internal conflicts and external threats from the Javanese Mataram kingdom led to Gelgel's decline.

Rise of Klungkung (1682):

Following Gelgel's fall, the seat of power moved to Klungkung, establishing the Gelgel dynasty's new capital under Dewa Agung Jambe. Klungkung emerged as a center of Balinese culture and a champion of tradition. This era saw the codification of the "Catur Arah" caste system, emphasizing social order and religious practices.

A Beacon of Culture:

Klungkung's reign as a dominant kingdom was marked by a flourishing of arts, literature, and dance. The "Wayang Wong" theatrical tradition and the "Kamasan" style of painting are attributed to this period. Klungkung also maintained a strong sense of Balinese identity, resisting external influences and maintaining a balance between different kingdoms on the island.

Puputan Klungkung (1908):

Dutch colonial ambitions clashed with Balinese resistance in the early 20th century. Klungkung's refusal to accept Dutch control over trade and surrender their royal regalia led to the tragic event of Puputan. This ritual suicide by the royal court and their followers in 1908 marked the end of Klungkung's independent rule.

Dutch Colonial Rule (1908 - 1949)

The Dutch takeover of Klungkung ushered in a new era of colonial governance:

Indirect Rule:
The Dutch adopted a strategy of indirect rule, allowing local leaders some autonomy while maintaining ultimate control. This system incorporated the existing caste system and appointed Rajas who would govern under Dutch supervision.

Economic Exploitation:
The Dutch focused on exploiting Bali's resources, particularly coffee production. This led to the introduction of forced cultivation practices that burdened the Balinese people.

Resistance and Change:
Balinese society did not passively accept Dutch rule. There were rebellions and uprisings throughout the colonial period. However, Dutch control also brought changes like improved infrastructure and healthcare.

Republic of Indonesia (1945/49 - Present)

Following Indonesia's independence in 1949, Bali, including Klungkung, became part of the new republic:

Integration and Decentralization:
Bali was initially incorporated as a province within Indonesia. Over time, Indonesia has adopted a more decentralized form of governance, granting greater autonomy to regions. Klungkung is now a regency within the province of Bali.

Preserving Traditions:
Despite modernization, Bali has strived to preserve its unique cultural heritage. Klungkung remains a center for traditional arts and continues to attract tourists interested in experiencing Balinese culture.

Challenges and Opportunities:
As part of Indonesia, Klungkung faces challenges like balancing tourism development with cultural preservation. However, opportunities exist for economic growth and improved living standards for its people.

review 2: A really interesting and beautiful place the museum is also really interesting with lots I formations, but you have to be careful not to be scammed by just so-called local guides who are not included in the price of the Museum and who aske you the payment at the end without giving you information in the beginning, and insist on the same prices as the entry ticket
review 3: Used to be a hall of justice in the past. The paintings on the roof of the two buildings are very detailed with punishments in hell and then marriage and dialy life.
review 4: This monument is in the middle of Semarapura city and reminds us about the Dutch colonization and many killings that Klungkung population suffer during the war against Westerners. Worth a visit, as you can dive into the history of this bloody wars between two opposite civilizations.
review 5: Very beautiful gardens around the monument. We were quite amazed to hear about its significance. Get tickets here to go to the gardens across the road.

name: PAPILAS Coffee & Roastery - Klungkung
address: Jalan Ngurah Rai No. 27, Semarapura, Semarapura, Tengah, Semarapura Kauh, Kec. Klungkung, Kabupaten Klungkung, Bali 80713, Indonesia
review 1:
The best coffee in town, the cappuccino is great. Doughnuts are freshly made every day which are tasty. I guess they have made some update on their pizza, better platter and tastier than I order the first time coming.

Unfortunately, the space is not big but still feel cosy to have a break. Also, there is a limited parking lot.

I usually come here when I am home. Highly recommend coffee shop in Klungkung.
review 2:
Great coffee and tea. Good food. Variety menu. Pizza was baked on a thin  dough, but top was a bit lacking of taste.  Bacon bread is something - cheese, bacon and vegetables baked in tempura baget- unusual and tasty.
The entire place is clean and cozy. Stuff is nice. Price is reasonable.
review 3: First of all, you get A LOT for your money. The cappuccino was great, we had French toast which was very affordable and tasted like double the price. The staff was very friendly and helpful, we drove 10 miles to get here and it was all worth it. Would come again and definitely recommending it to everyone in the area.
review 4: After a long and hot road trip from west side of Bali. We decided to take a few hours break at this cafe. The smoking and non-smoking area are divided (non-smoking = air-con) and the decor is quaint industrial. The tea and coffee is pretty good. And we were spoilt by choices of mini donuts, of which all are airy and fluffy. We ordered pastas for lunch and they were very yummy, but perhaps a bit too small portion for a meal. However it was okay for us, since we ate our donuts as appetizers. Services are friendly and nice. Plenty of plugs if one would like to hang out for a few hours.
review 5: Went to Papila‚Äôs Coffee a bit late at night @ 9pm the owner & staff are fun friendly. I do really recommend the ‚ÄúSpring‚Äù tea, but the variant of the Tea are superb! Tried the Meat Lovers Pizza, super tasty and crispy! There‚Äôs a promo buy 1 get 1 free for all beverages from 8-11am . Will be back for sure!ü•∞
